title: Marine Spatial Planning Project - Scope of Work and Deliverables
text: Location: Mkoani (Pemba) and Mkuranga (Pwani Region), Tanzania

title: Marine Spatial Planning Project - Scope of Work and Deliverables
text: Location: Mkoani (Pemba) and Mkuranga (Pwani Region), Tanzania

title: Marine Spatial Planning Project - Scope of Work and Deliverables
text:
Project Overview
This Marine Spatial Planning project aims to develop comprehensive spatial plans for sustainable coastal and marine resource management in Mkoani and Mkuranga districts. The initiative integrates scientific research, stakeholder engagement, and participatory planning to support evidence-based marine governance and blue economy development.



Collaborative Marine Spatial Planning: Stakeholders and community leaders engage in participatory discussions to shape sustainable management strategies for coastal Tanzania

title: Marine Spatial Planning Project - Scope of Work and Deliverables
text:
Scope of Work and Deliverables

1. Inception Report
Target Completion Date: 15 September 2025
Objectives: Establish project foundations, clarify roles and responsibilities, and align stakeholders on project goals and implementation approach.


Deliverable: A detailed inception report including:

Comprehensive project methodology and approach
Detailed activity schedule and timeline
Data requirements and collection protocols
Stakeholder engagement and consultation plan
Institutional coordination framework













2. Biodiversity Assessment and Trend Analysis
Target Completion Date: 25 January 2026
Lead: Siajali Pamba under guidance of Masumbuko Semba
Objectives: Establish baseline biodiversity conditions and identify temporal trends to inform conservation priorities.
Deliverable: A report on data collection, detailed maps and ground truthing, showing:



Decadal trends in biodiversity loss and gain across Tanzania (focusing on mangrove ecosystems)
Regional context and significance for marine conservation
Spatial distribution maps of key biodiversity indicators
Ground-truthed field observations and validation data
High-resolution geospatial mapping of mangrove loss/gain trends for coastal districts
Restoration priority areas for carbon offset schemes and climate mitigation













3. Field Data Collection and Mapping
Target Completion Date: 25 January 2026
Lead: Masumbuko Semba with guidance from Siajali Pamba
Objectives: Collect primary data across multiple disciplines and develop spatial datasets to support planning decisions.
Deliverable: Comprehensive field data collection and map layer development:



Physical data: Bathymetry, coastal morphology, oceanographic parameters, seabed morphology, ocean currents, sea level trends, salinity, temperature, acidification, upwelling zones
Biological data: Fish populations, coral reef conditions, seagrass beds, biodiversity hotspots, mangroves, critical fish habitats, migratory corridors (turtles, sharks)
Geomorphological data: Habitat classifications, erosion zones, ecosystem boundaries
Socioeconomic data: Fisher demographics, livelihood patterns, resource use intensity, settlements, infrastructure, tourism hubs
Marine resource use data: Fishing effort distribution, gear types, seasonal patterns, aquaculture/mariculture zones, fish landing sites, CFMAs, CMAs, BMUs  










Data Sources: ESA data (10m resolution), NAFORMA, TAN-Sea map, ECAS data, TPDC (oil and gas), open street maps, Frame survey data



4. Ecosystem Services Valuation
Target Completion Date: 31 March 2026
Lead: Gervas Maro with assistance from Julius Francis
Objectives: Quantify the economic value of marine ecosystems to support conservation and sustainable use arguments.
Deliverable: A comprehensive economic valuation report including:



Baseline valuation of coastal and marine ecosystem goods and services in USD
Spatial mapping of classified ecosystem assets and service categories
Classification and cataloging of coastal and marine assets with focus on key habitats (mangroves, coral, seagrasses, beaches)
Ecosystem services analysis through comparative risk analysis:

Provisioning services (food provisioning from marine fish catch, mariculture, agriculture, raw materials, fuelwood, timber)
Regulating/supporting services (carbon sequestration, habitat maintenance, regulation of extreme events)
Cultural services (tourism, recreation, ecotourism)















5. Bio-Economic Cost-Benefit Analysis
Target Completion Date: 31 March 2026
Lead: Emmanuel Mpina with inputs from project team members
Objectives: Demonstrate the economic case for sustainable marine management and identify financing pathways aligned with national priorities.
Deliverable: A detailed cost-benefit analysis report evaluating proposed bioeconomic activities:



Financial feasibility assessments for:

New Marine Protected Areas (MPAs)
Carbon offset co-managed sites
Octopus closure sites
Seaweed farming plots
Pelagic anchovies (dagaa) initiatives
Alternative livelihoods (e.g., seaweed farming, eco-tourism)

Proposed green and blue finance instruments for funding:

Local tax mechanisms
Private investor partnerships
Climate finance instruments
Conservation trust funds
Payment for ecosystem services schemes




Policy guidance to support:

Blue economy growth and diversification
Biodiversity conservation and ecosystem restoration
Ecosystem resilience and climate adaptation
Alignment with national climate action plans and SDGs
Upscaling of successful initiatives













6. Interactive Digital Visualization Platform
Target Completion Date: 1 December 2025 - 15 April 2026
Lead: Masumbuko Semba and Emmanuel Mpina Objectives: Make complex spatial and economic data accessible and actionable for diverse stakeholders. Deliverable: An integrated digital visualization tool featuring:



Web Maps: Geospatial visualizations displaying:

Degraded hotspots in Tanzania requiring restoration
Marine biodiversity loss and gain spatial trends
State of Mkuranga and Mkoani districts showing physical features, ecological assets, and health indicators
Ecosystem valuation data and economic analysis results
Cost-benefit analysis for implementation of environmental and socioeconomic measures
Blue economy initiatives and innovations

District Focus: Detailed visualizations and statistics for Mkuranga and Mkoani:

Ecosystem status indicators
Biodiversity patterns and trends
Ecosystem service spatial distribution




Socioeconomic context and livelihood dependencies
Climate vulnerability assessments
Areas of potential marine resource-use conflicts
Community-priority conservation areas and fisheries closure areas
Blue carbon opportunities

Land Cover Change in Mkuranga District
text:
Spatial patterns in land cover are the local arrangements and configurations of different land use types across a landscape. Rather than simply knowing what proportion of an area is forest or cropland, understanding the pattern of these land covers reveals much more about ecosystem function and human land use practices. For example, fragmented forests interspersed with agriculture indicate different management histories and conservation challenges than consolidated forest blocks.






Spatial signatures provide a quantitative framework for capturing these patterns. They encode information about how land cover types are spatially organized‚Äîwhether they form large contiguous patches, are highly fragmented, or follow specific spatial arrangements. In this post, I‚Äôll demonstrate how to analyze and track temporal changes in land cover patterns across Mkuranga District and use visual analysis to identify drivers of landscape transformation in this critical coastal region.

title: Land Cover Change in Mkuranga District
text:
Spatial patterns in land cover are the local arrangements and configurations of different land use types across a landscape. Rather than simply knowing what proportion of an area is forest or cropland, understanding the pattern of these land covers reveals much more about ecosystem function and human land use practices. For example, fragmented forests interspersed with agriculture indicate different management histories and conservation challenges than consolidated forest blocks.






Spatial signatures provide a quantitative framework for capturing these patterns. They encode information about how land cover types are spatially organized‚Äîwhether they form large contiguous patches, are highly fragmented, or follow specific spatial arrangements. In this post, I‚Äôll demonstrate how to analyze and track temporal changes in land cover patterns across Mkuranga District and use visual analysis to identify drivers of landscape transformation in this critical coastal region.

title: Land Cover Change in Mkuranga District
text:
Loading and Preparing the Data
Working with spatial raster data requires careful data loading and preprocessing to ensure consistent and accurate analysis. We begin by loading specialized R packages designed for spatial analysis: terra for raster operations, sf for vector geometries, and tidyterra to bridge spatial data with tidyverse workflows. These packages provide efficient tools for reading, manipulating, and visualizing large spatial datasets.


Code
library(sf)
library(terra)
library(tidyterra)
library(tidyverse)
require(tidyplots)
# library(webr)
require(patchwork)
require(gt)
require(echarts4r)


We source ESA WorldCover 10m resolution land cover data for Mkuranga District, located on mainland Tanzania‚Äôs Pwani Region. This district encompasses critical coastal ecosystems where terrestrial and marine habitats interface. Converting these rasters to factors (categorical data) is essential‚Äîit tells R that the numeric values represent discrete land cover categories rather than continuous measurements, which enables proper labeling and visualization.


Code
lulc_2020 <- greenSD::get_esa_wc(
    bbox = mkoani_bbox, 
    year = 2021,
    # place = 'Dar es Salaam, Tanzania', 
    datatype = "landcover"
    )

lulc_2020 |> 
    terra::writeRaster(
        filename = 'data/mkuranga_lulc_2021.tif',
         overwrite=TRUE, 
         datatype='INT1U'
    )


Load the raster data for Mkuranga District:


Code
#posts/lulc_change/

mkuranga_lc20 = terra::rast('mkuranga_lulc_2020.tif')  |> 
    terra::crop(terra::ext(39.2, 39.48, -7.55, -7.1), mask = TRUE) |> 
    as.factor()

mkuranga_lc21 = terra::rast('mkuranga_lulc_2021.tif')  |> 
    terra::crop(terra::ext(39.2, 39.48, -7.55, -7.1), mask = TRUE) |> 
    as.factor()

title: Land Cover Change in Mkuranga District
text:
Creating a Standardized Color Scheme
Consistent color representation across all visualizations is crucial for effective communication and reproducibility in scientific analyses. We create a reference dataframe (worldcover_df) that maps each ESA WorldCover land cover category to a standardized hex color code based on official ESA specifications. This single reference ensures that forest always appears as dark green (#006400), water as blue (#0064c8), and so forth across all figures.


Code
# Based on official ESA WorldCover specifications
worldcover_df = data.frame(
  value = c(10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90, 95, 100),
  label = c("Tree cover", "Shrubland", "Grassland", "Cropland", 
            "Built-up", "Bare/sparse vegetation", "Snow and ice",
            "Water bodies", "Herbaceous wetland", 
            "Mangroves", "Moss and lichen"),
  color = c("#006400", "#ffbb22", "#ffff4c", "#f096ff", "#fa0000", 
            "#b4b4b4", "#f0f0f0", "#0064c8", "#0096a0", "#00cf75", "#fae6a0")
)


Beyond colors, we embed this metadata directly into our raster objects using the levels() and coltab() functions. This embeds both the categorical labels and color palette into the raster structure itself, making the visualizations self-contained and reproducible. Any downstream analysis or visualization automatically uses these definitions, eliminating inconsistencies and the need to repeatedly specify colors and labels.


Code
# Set levels with labels
levels(mkuranga_lc20) = worldcover_df |> select(value, label)

# Embed color palette into rasters
coltab(mkuranga_lc20) = worldcover_df |> select(value, color)

# Set levels with labels
levels(mkuranga_lc21) = worldcover_df |> select(value, label)

# Embed color palette into rasters
coltab(mkuranga_lc21) = worldcover_df |> select(value, color)


mkuranga_lc = c(mkuranga_lc20, mkuranga_lc21)
  names(mkuranga_lc) = c('lc_2020', 'lc_2021')

# mkuranga_lc |> plot()

title: Land Cover Change in Mkuranga District
section: Land Cover Distribution in Mkuranga District
text:
Land Cover Distribution in Mkuranga District
Figure¬†1 is animated interactive pie chart that displays the relative abundance of each land cover type in Mkuranga District in 2020. Hover over each segment to view the exact pixel count for that category. The chart provides a quick visual summary of landscape composition, showing which land cover types dominate the district. For area calculations in hectares, pixel counts were mutiplied by 100 (since each pixel represents a 10m √ó 10m area, equaling 100 m2).








Figure¬†1: Land Cover Composition of Mkuranga District

title: Land Cover Change in Mkuranga District
Land Cover Change in Mkuranga District
text:
Understanding Land Cover Transitions
Beyond static snapshots, understanding how land cover types change from one category to another provides critical insights into ecosystem dynamics and land use trajectories. A transition matrix‚Äîalso called a cross-tabulation or contingency table‚Äîreveals exactly which land cover types are converting to which alternatives. For example, are forests converting directly to cropland (indicating clearing for agriculture), or is forest first transitioning to grassland/shrubland (indicating intermediate disturbance)? These transition pathways reflect different management practices and have distinct implications for ecosystem recovery and conservation strategy.
The transition matrix quantifies all land cover changes occurring between 2020 and 2021 in Mkuranga District. Rows represent the 2020 baseline condition and columns represent the 2021 outcome. Diagonal values (where row and column match) indicate persistence‚Äîareas where the land cover remained unchanged. Off-diagonal values indicate transitions‚Äîareas where land cover shifted from one type to another. This granular perspective reveals not just net changes in composition, but the specific pathways through which landscape transformation is occurring in Mkuranga.
Understanding these transitions is essential for marine spatial planning in Mkuranga because different conversion pathways have different implications for coastal water quality and fishery productivity. Forest-to-cropland transitions typically increase nutrient and sediment runoff that degrade nearshore water quality. Mangrove loss directly reduces fish nursery habitat and coastal protection. Grassland-to-cropland transitions may increase soil erosion and sedimentation into coastal zones. Forest-to-built-up transitions concentrate impacts affecting local hydrology. By identifying the dominant transition pathways in Mkuranga, managers can target land-based interventions precisely where they will have the greatest benefit for coastal and fishery ecosystem health.


Code
change = diffeR::crosstabm(mkuranga_lc[[1]],mkuranga_lc[[2]], percent = FALSE)
labels_lulc = worldcover_df$label[c(-7,-11)]
rownames(change) = labels_lulc
colnames(change) = labels_lulc
change_ha = (change*100)/4063.74  # convert to hectares




Code
change_ha |> 
    round(1) |> 
    as_tibble(rownames = "lc_2020") |> 
    gt::gt() |>
    gt::tab_header(
        title = "Land Cover Transition Matrix",
        subtitle = "Area (hectares) of each land cover type in 2020 converting to 2021 categories in Mkuranga District"
    ) |>
    gt::opt_stylize(style = 1) |>
    gt::tab_style(
        style = gt::cell_fill(color = "#e8f4f8"),
        locations = gt::cells_body()
    ) |>
    gt::fmt_number(columns = -lc_2020, decimals = 1)




Table¬†1: Land Cover Transition Matrix for Mkuranga District (2020-2021). Values represent area in hectares. Rows indicate 2020 baseline land cover type; columns indicate 2021 outcome. Diagonal values show persistence (no change); off-diagonal values show transitions between categories. Large values in off-diagonal cells indicate active land conversion. For example, the Tree cover‚ÜíCropland cell reveals forest clearing for agriculture. The Mangrove‚Üíother transitions reveal changes in this critical coastal habitat.

Interpreting the transition matrix: Read each row to understand what happened to that 2020 land cover type in Mkuranga. For instance, the ‚ÄúTree cover‚Äù row shows how forest pixels were distributed across different categories in 2021. The largest value in that row indicates the most common fate of forests‚Äîwhether persistence, conversion to agriculture, or other uses. Summing across a row gives the total area of that land cover type in 2020; summing down a column gives the total area of that type in 2021. Values on the diagonal represent stability‚Äîareas where land cover persisted unchanged and therefore represent the landscape‚Äôs resilience to conversion.


Code
change_ha |> 
    round(1) |> 
    as_tibble() |> 
    mutate('x2020' = labels_lulc, .before = `Tree cover`) |> 
    pivot_longer(-x2020, names_to = 'x2021', values_to = 'area_ha') |> 
    gt::gt() |>
    gt::opt_stylize(style = 1) |>
    gt::fmt_number(columns = -area_ha, decimals = 1) |> 
    gt::cols_label(
      x2020 = "2020",
      x2021 = "2021",
      area_ha = "Area (hectares)"
    ) |> 
    gt::tab_spanner(columns = 1:2, label = "Land Cover") |>
    gt::fmt_number(columns = area_ha, decimals = 1)




Table¬†2: Detailed Land Cover Transitions for Mkuranga District (2020-2021). Each row shows a specific transition from a 2020 land cover type to a 2021 outcome, with the corresponding area in hectares. This format facilitates filtering to identify specific conversion pathways of interest‚Äîfor example, finding all areas converted from Forest to Cropland, or from Mangrove to other land cover types.

terra: Hijmans, R. J. (2024). terra: Spatial data analysis. R package version 1.7-80. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=terra - Core package for reading, writing, and manipulating raster (gridded) data - Used for loading ESA WorldCover tif files and raster operations
tidyterra: Hernang√≥mez, D. (2024). tidyterra: Tidy tools for spatial data. R package version 0.5.2. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=tidyterra - Bridges terra raster objects with tidyverse workflows - Enables piping and dplyr-style operations on spatial data
sf: Pebesma, E. (2018). Simple Features for R: Standardized Support for Spatial Vector Data. The R Journal, 10(1), 439‚Äì446. https://doi.org/10.32614/RJ-2018-009 - Handles vector spatial data and CRS operations - Provides spatial analysis and transformation capabilities


Data Visualization
ggplot2: Wickham, H. (2016). ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis (2nd ed.). Springer-Verlag New York. https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/ - Foundational grammar of graphics package for creating publication-quality figures - Used with tidyterra for spatial raster visualization
tidyplots: Slowikowski, K. (2024). tidyplots: Tidy plots using ggplot2. R package. https://github.com/slowkow/tidyplots - Provides ggplot2 theme customization and wrapper functions - Used for creating stacked bar and area charts with consistent styling
gt: Iannone, R., Cheng, J., & Schloerke, B. (2024). gt: Easily Create Presentation-Ready Display Tables. R package version 0.10.1. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=gt - Enables creation of formatted, publication-ready tables - Used for displaying transition matrices with professional styling and number formatting
patchwork: Pedersen, T. L. (2024). patchwork: The Composer of Plots. R package version 1.2.1. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=patchwork - Simplifies composition of multiple ggplot2 plots - Imported for multi-plot layouts and figure combinations
webr: Andrews, B. (2024). webr: Interactive Graphics in R. R package. https://github.com/bwlewis/webr - Provides interactive visualization capabilities - Used for creating interactive pie and donut charts


Data Manipulation and Analysis
dplyr: Wickham, H., Fran√ßois, R., Henry, L., M√ºller, K., & Posit Software, PBC. (2024). dplyr: A Grammar of Data Manipulation. R package version 1.1.4. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=dplyr - Part of tidyverse ecosystem for data transformation - Used implicitly through pipes (|>) for filtering, joining, and mutating land cover data
diffeR: Pontius Jr., R. G., & Millones, M. (2011). Death to Kappa: birth of quantity disagreement and allocation disagreement for accuracy assessment. International Journal of Remote Sensing, 32(15), 4407‚Äì4429. - Specialized package for land use/cover change detection and comparison - crosstabm() function creates transition/contingency matrices from paired rasters
tidyverse: Wickham, H., Averick, M., Bryan, J., et al.¬†(2019). Welcome to the tidyverse. Journal of Open Source Software, 4(43), 1686. https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.01686 - Meta-package providing consistent data manipulation philosophy - Core dependency for all data processing workflows


Data Sources
ESA WorldCover: Zanaga, D., Van De Kerchove, R., Daems, D., De Keersmaecker, W., Brockmann, C., Kirches, G., ‚Ä¶ & Arino, O. (2021). ESA WorldCover 10 m 2020 v100. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.5571498 - 10-meter resolution global land cover dataset - Contains 11 land cover classes based on Sentinel-1 and Sentinel-2 satellite data

title: Marine Spatial Planning
text:
This Marine Spatial Planning initiative focuses on developing sustainable coastal resource management strategies in Mkoani (Pemba Island), Zanzibar and Mkuranga districts within the Pwani region of mainland Tanzania. The consultancy integrates scientific research, stakeholder engagement, and participatory planning to support evidence-based marine governance.

title: Marine Spatial Planning
text:
About the Consultancy
The Marine Spatial Planning Consultancy for Mkoani-Pemba and Mkuranga is a collaborative initiative led by the University of Dar es Salaam, School of Aquatic Sciences and Fisheries Technology (SOAF) in partnership with coastal communities and government authorities. The consultancy aims to create comprehensive spatial plans that balance conservation objectives with sustainable use of marine resources.

Study Sites: Mkoani and Mkuranga
Mkoani, Pemba (Unguja Region) and Mkuranga (Pwani Region) represent key coastal areas with significant fishing activities and diverse marine ecosystems. These sites were selected for:

Strategic importance for Indian Ocean fisheries
Presence of multiple livelihood communities dependent on marine resources
High biodiversity value and conservation potential
Need for improved governance and management frameworks



Consultancy Focus Areas
The initiative addresses key marine planning challenges through:







Focus Area
Objective




Fisheries Management
Develop sustainable fishing zones and seasonal closures based on resource dynamics


Biodiversity Conservation
Identify and protect critical marine habitats and species


Coastal Communities
Support livelihoods while ensuring resource sustainability


Climate Resilience
Build adaptive management strategies for environmental changes


Governance Coordination
Strengthen institutional frameworks for marine resource management





Financial Support
This consultancy is financially supported by the Nairobi Convention Secretariat, which provides funding through its marine and coastal area management programs. The Nairobi Convention‚Äôs support reflects Tanzania‚Äôs commitment to regional cooperation on marine conservation and sustainable resource management in the Western Indian Ocean region. Some of the key institution partners include:

Department of Blue Economy, Vice President‚Äôs Office
Ministry of Blue Economy, Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar
University of Dar es Salaam, SOAF** (Lead Institution)
Nelson Mandela African Institution of Science and Technology (NM-AIST)
The Nature Conservancy, Tanzania**







Note



This initiative operates within the framework of Tanzania‚Äôs marine conservation policies and supports the implementation of Marine Spatial Planning in Tanzania.

title: Marine Spatial Planning
text:
Spatial Planning Approach
This initiative employs a participatory and science-based approach to marine spatial planning, drawing on:

Community engagement: Inclusive consultation with fishers, boat owners, and coastal residents
Ecological data: Scientific surveys of fish populations, habitats, and marine biodiversity
Socioeconomic analysis: Assessment of livelihood patterns and economic dependencies on marine resources
Institutional coordination: Collaboration with district authorities and national management frameworks
Adaptive management: Iterative planning process with monitoring and refinement

title: Marine Spatial Planning
text:
Consultancy Outcomes
Through this initiative, stakeholders will:

‚úì Develop comprehensive marine spatial plans for Mkoani and Mkuranga districts
‚úì Establish evidence-based zones for fishing, conservation, and sustainable use
‚úì Strengthen coordination among government agencies, communities, and resource users
‚úì Build local capacity for marine resource monitoring and adaptive management
‚úì Contribute to Tanzania‚Äôs marine conservation and sustainable development goals

title: Land Cover Patterns in Mkoani and Mkuranga Districts
text:
Spatial patterns in land cover are the local arrangements and configurations of different land use types across a landscape. Rather than simply knowing what proportion of an area is forest or cropland, understanding the pattern of these land covers reveals much more about ecosystem function and human land use practices. For example, fragmented forests interspersed with agriculture indicate different management histories and conservation challenges than consolidated forest blocks.
Spatial signatures provide a quantitative framework for capturing these patterns. They encode information about how land cover types are spatially organized‚Äîwhether they form large contiguous patches, are highly fragmented, or follow specific spatial arrangements. In this post, I‚Äôll demonstrate how to compare spatial signatures between two coastal Tanzanian districts and use visual analysis to identify their characteristic land cover patterns.

title: Land Cover Patterns in Mkoani and Mkuranga Districts
text:
Spatial patterns in land cover are the local arrangements and configurations of different land use types across a landscape. Rather than simply knowing what proportion of an area is forest or cropland, understanding the pattern of these land covers reveals much more about ecosystem function and human land use practices. For example, fragmented forests interspersed with agriculture indicate different management histories and conservation challenges than consolidated forest blocks.
Spatial signatures provide a quantitative framework for capturing these patterns. They encode information about how land cover types are spatially organized‚Äîwhether they form large contiguous patches, are highly fragmented, or follow specific spatial arrangements. In this post, I‚Äôll demonstrate how to compare spatial signatures between two coastal Tanzanian districts and use visual analysis to identify their characteristic land cover patterns.

title: Land Cover Patterns in Mkoani and Mkuranga Districts
text:
Loading and Preparing the Data
Working with spatial raster data requires careful data loading and preprocessing to ensure consistent and accurate analysis. We begin by loading specialized R packages designed for spatial analysis: terra for raster operations, sf for vector geometries, and tidyterra to bridge spatial data with tidyverse workflows. These packages provide efficient tools for reading, manipulating, and visualizing large spatial datasets.
We source ESA WorldCover 10m resolution land cover data for our study areas. The Mkoani district data covers the Pemba region, while Mkuranga district is defined by a specific geographic extent. Converting these rasters to factors (categorical data) is essential‚Äîit tells R that the numeric values represent discrete land cover categories rather than continuous measurements, which enables proper labeling and visualization.


Code
library(sf)
library(terra)
library(tidyterra)
library(tidyverse)
library(webr)


We‚Äôll work with ESA WorldCover 10m resolution land cover data for two districts in Tanzania. The data represent land cover types in a part of Tanzania in 2020 at 10 m resolution. We also load the boundaries of protected areas in the region.


Code
pemba_lulc = terra::rast('../data/mkoani_lulc_2021.tif') |> 
    as.factor()

mkuranga_lulc = terra::rast('../data/mkuranga_lulc_2021.tif') |> 
    terra::crop(terra::ext(39.2, 39.48, -7.55, -7.1), mask = TRUE) |> 
    as.factor()

title: Land Cover Patterns in Mkoani and Mkuranga Districts
text:
Creating a Standardized Color Scheme
Consistent color representation across all visualizations is crucial for effective communication and reproducibility in scientific analyses. We create a reference dataframe (worldcover_df) that maps each ESA WorldCover land cover category to a standardized hex color code based on official ESA specifications. This single reference ensures that forest always appears as dark green (#006400), water as blue (#0064c8), and so forth across all figures.


Code
# Based on official ESA WorldCover specifications
worldcover_df = data.frame(
  value = c(10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90, 95, 100),
  label = c("Tree cover", "Shrubland", "Grassland", "Cropland", 
            "Built-up", "Bare/sparse vegetation", "Snow and ice",
            "Water bodies", "Herbaceous wetland", 
            "Mangroves", "Moss and lichen"),
  color = c("#006400", "#ffbb22", "#ffff4c", "#f096ff", "#fa0000", 
            "#b4b4b4", "#f0f0f0", "#0064c8", "#0096a0", "#00cf75", "#fae6a0")
)


Beyond colors, we embed this metadata directly into our raster objects using the levels() and coltab() functions. This embeds both the categorical labels and color palette into the raster structure itself, making the visualizations self-contained and reproducible. Any downstream analysis or visualization automatically uses these definitions, eliminating inconsistencies and the need to repeatedly specify colors and labels.


Code
# Set levels with labels
levels(pemba_lulc) = worldcover_df |> select(value, label)
levels(mkuranga_lulc) = worldcover_df |> select(value, label)

# Embed color palette into rasters
coltab(pemba_lulc) = worldcover_df |> select(value, color)
coltab(mkuranga_lulc) = worldcover_df |> select(value, color)

title: Land Cover Patterns in Mkoani and Mkuranga Districts
Land Cover Patterns in Mkoani and Mkuranga Districts
text:
Key Observations
The land cover analysis reveals that both Mkoani and Mkuranga districts maintain forest as their dominant ecosystem type, providing critical ecosystem services including carbon sequestration, watershed protection, and biodiversity habitat. However, the spatial arrangement and composition of other land cover types differ between regions, reflecting distinct management histories and development trajectories. The presence of significant agricultural lands alongside forests suggests these areas support mixed subsistence and commercial activities.
These foundational observations establish the baseline for deeper spatial pattern analysis. Understanding composition alone is insufficient‚Äîthe configuration of these land covers (their fragmentation, connectivity, and spatial arrangement) determines ecosystem resilience and management effectiveness. The next phase of analysis will quantify these spatial patterns using advanced techniques to identify areas of unique land cover organization.

title: Land Cover Patterns in Mkoani and Mkuranga Districts
text:
Next Steps
With these baseline land cover maps and compositions established, we are now positioned to explore more sophisticated spatial analysis techniques. The motif R package provides powerful methods to calculate spatial signatures‚Äîquantitative summaries of the local spatial arrangement of land covers. These signatures enable us to compare regions not just by what land covers they contain, but by how those covers are spatially organized.
Future analyses will employ spatial signature matching to identify areas with similar land cover patterns, detect changes in spatial organization between time periods, and pinpoint regions with unique or anomalous spatial configurations. These advanced methods reveal landscape-level changes that simple composition analysis cannot capture, enabling more targeted conservation and land management strategies tailored to regional characteristics.

Spatial signatures provide a quantitative framework for capturing these patterns. In this post, I‚Äôll demonstrate how to analyze and track temporal changes in land cover patterns across Mkoani District and use visual analysis to identify drivers of landscape transformation in this critical island ecosystem.

Working with spatial raster data requires careful data loading and preprocessing to ensure consistent and accurate analysis. We begin by loading specialized R packages designed for spatial analysis: terra for raster operations, sf for vector geometries, and tidyterra to bridge spatial data with tidyverse workflows. These packages provide efficient tools for reading, manipulating, and visualizing large spatial datasets.
We source ESA WorldCover 10m resolution land cover data for Mkoani District, located on Pemba Island in northern Tanzania. This island district encompasses critical coastal ecosystems where terrestrial and marine habitats interface. Converting these rasters to factors (categorical data) is essential‚Äîit tells R that the numeric values represent discrete land cover categories rather than continuous measurements, which enables proper labeling and visualization.


Code
library(sf)
library(terra)
library(tidyterra)
library(tidyverse)
require(tidyplots)
# library(webr)
require(patchwork)
require(gt)




Code
lulc_2020 <- greenSD::get_esa_wc(
    bbox = mkoani_bbox, 
    year = 2021,
    # place = 'Dar es Salaam, Tanzania', 
    datatype = "landcover"
    )

lulc_2020 |> 
    terra::writeRaster(
        filename = 'data/mkoani_lulc_2021.tif',
         overwrite=TRUE, 
         datatype='INT1U'
    )


Load the raster data for Mkoani District:


Code
pemba_lc20 = terra::rast('mkoani_lulc_2020.tif') |> 
    as.factor()

pemba_lc21 = terra::rast('mkoani_lulc_2021.tif') |> 
    as.factor()

title: Land Cover Patterns in Mkoani District
text:
Creating a Standardized Color Scheme
Consistent color representation across all visualizations is crucial for effective communication and reproducibility in scientific analyses. We create a reference dataframe (worldcover_df) that maps each ESA WorldCover land cover category to a standardized hex color code based on official ESA specifications. This single reference ensures that forest always appears as dark green (#006400), water as blue (#0064c8), and so forth across all figures.


Code
# Based on official ESA WorldCover specifications
worldcover_df = data.frame(
  value = c(10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90, 95, 100),
  label = c("Tree cover", "Shrubland", "Grassland", "Cropland", 
            "Built-up", "Bare/sparse vegetation", "Snow and ice",
            "Water bodies", "Herbaceous wetland", 
            "Mangroves", "Moss and lichen"),
  color = c("#006400", "#ffbb22", "#ffff4c", "#f096ff", "#fa0000", 
            "#b4b4b4", "#f0f0f0", "#0064c8", "#0096a0", "#00cf75", "#fae6a0")
)


Beyond colors, we embed this metadata directly into our raster objects using the levels() and coltab() functions. This embeds both the categorical labels and color palette into the raster structure itself, making the visualizations self-contained and reproducible. Any downstream analysis or visualization automatically uses these definitions, eliminating inconsistencies and the need to repeatedly specify colors and labels.


Code
# Set levels with labels
levels(pemba_lc20) = worldcover_df |> select(value, label)

# Embed color palette into rasters
coltab(pemba_lc20) = worldcover_df |> select(value, color)

# Set levels with labels
levels(pemba_lc21) = worldcover_df |> select(value, label)

# Embed color palette into rasters
coltab(pemba_lc21) = worldcover_df |> select(value, color)


pemba_lc = c(pemba_lc20, pemba_lc21)
  names(pemba_lc) = c('lc_2020', 'lc_2021')

# pemba_lc |> plot()

title: Land Cover Patterns in Mkoani District
Land Cover Patterns in Mkoani District
text:
Understanding Land Cover Transitions
Beyond static snapshots, understanding how land cover types change from one category to another provides critical insights into ecosystem dynamics and land use trajectories. A transition matrix‚Äîalso called a cross-tabulation or contingency table‚Äîreveals exactly which land cover types are converting to which alternatives. For example, are forests converting directly to cropland (indicating clearing for agriculture), or is forest first transitioning to grassland/shrubland (indicating intermediate disturbance)? These transition pathways reflect different management practices and have distinct implications for ecosystem recovery and conservation strategy.
The transition matrix quantifies all land cover changes occurring between 2020 and 2021 in Mkoani district. Rows represent the 2020 baseline condition and columns represent the 2021 outcome. Diagonal values (where row and column match) indicate persistence‚Äîareas where the land cover remained unchanged. Off-diagonal values indicate transitions‚Äîareas where land cover shifted from one type to another. This granular perspective reveals not just net changes in composition, but the specific pathways through which landscape transformation is occurring.
Understanding these transitions is essential for marine spatial planning because different conversion pathways have different implications for coastal water quality. Forest-to-cropland transitions typically increase nutrient and sediment runoff. Forest-to-built-up transitions concentrate impacts in specific locations affecting local hydrology. Grassland-to-cropland transitions may increase soil erosion. By identifying the dominant transition pathways, managers can target interventions precisely where they will have the greatest benefit for coastal ecosystem health.


Code
change = diffeR::crosstabm(pemba_lc[[1]],pemba_lc[[2]], percent = FALSE)
labels_lulc = worldcover_df$label[c(-7,-11)]
rownames(change) = labels_lulc
colnames(change) = labels_lulc
change_ha = (change*100)/4063.74  # convert to hectares




Code
change_ha |> 
    round(1) |> 
    as_tibble(rownames = "lc_2020") |> 
    gt::gt() |>
    # gt::tab_header(
    #     title = "Land Cover Transition Matrix",
    #     subtitle = "Area (hectares) of each land cover type in 2020 converting to 2021 categories in Mkoani District"
    # ) |>
    gt::opt_stylize(style = 1) |>
    gt::tab_style(
        style = gt::cell_fill(color = "#e8f4f8"),
        locations = gt::cells_body()
    ) |>
    gt::fmt_number(columns = -lc_2020, decimals = 1)




Table¬†1: Land Cover Transition Matrix for Mkoani District (2020-2021). Values represent area in hectares. Rows indicate 2020 baseline land cover type; columns indicate 2021 outcome. Diagonal values show persistence (no change); off-diagonal values show transitions between categories. Large values in off-diagonal cells indicate active land conversion. For example, the Tree cover‚ÜíCropland cell reveals forest clearing for agriculture. The Tree cover‚ÜíHerbaceous wetland cell suggests forest areas becoming more waterlogged or managed for wetland agriculture.

Interpreting the transition matrix: Read each row to understand what happened to that 2020 land cover type. For instance, the ‚ÄúTree cover‚Äù row shows how forest pixels were distributed across different categories in 2021. The largest value in that row indicates the most common fate of forests. Summing across a row gives the total area of that land cover type in 2020; summing down a column gives the total area of that type in 2021. Values on the diagonal represent stability‚Äîareas where land cover persisted unchanged and therefore represent the landscape‚Äôs resilience to conversion.


Code
change_ha |> 
    round(1) |> 
    as_tibble() |> 
    mutate('x2020' = labels_lulc, .before = `Tree cover`) |> 
    pivot_longer(-x2020, names_to = 'x2021', values_to = 'area_ha') |> 
    gt::gt() |>
    gt::opt_stylize(style = 1) |>
    gt::fmt_number(columns = -area_ha, decimals = 1) |> 
    gt::cols_label(
      x2020 = "2020",
      x2021 = "2021",
      area_ha = "Area (hectares)"
    ) |> 
    gt::tab_spanner(columns = 1:2, label = "Land Cover") |>
    gt::fmt_number(columns = area_ha, decimals = 1)




Table¬†2: Long-Format Land Cover Transition Matrix for Mkoani District (2020-2021). Each row represents a 2020 land cover type (x2020), and each column represents the corresponding 2021 outcome (x2021). The area_ha column quantifies the area in hectares transitioning from each 2020 category to each 2021 category.

title: Land Cover Patterns in Mkoani District
text:
References

Spatial Analysis and Raster Processing
terra: Hijmans, R. J. (2024). terra: Spatial data analysis. R package version 1.7-80. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=terra - Core package for reading, writing, and manipulating raster (gridded) data - Used for loading ESA WorldCover tif files and raster operations
tidyterra: Hernang√≥mez, D. (2024). tidyterra: Tidy tools for spatial data. R package version 0.5.2. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=tidyterra - Bridges terra raster objects with tidyverse workflows - Enables piping and dplyr-style operations on spatial data
sf: Pebesma, E. (2018). Simple Features for R: Standardized Support for Spatial Vector Data. The R Journal, 10(1), 439‚Äì446. https://doi.org/10.32614/RJ-2018-009 - Handles vector spatial data and CRS operations - Provides spatial analysis and transformation capabilities


Data Visualization
ggplot2: Wickham, H. (2016). ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis (2nd ed.). Springer-Verlag New York. https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/ - Foundational grammar of graphics package for creating publication-quality figures - Used with tidyterra for spatial raster visualization
tidyplots: Slowikowski, K. (2024). tidyplots: Tidy plots using ggplot2. R package. https://github.com/slowkow/tidyplots - Provides ggplot2 theme customization and wrapper functions - Used for creating stacked bar and area charts with consistent styling
gt: Iannone, R., Cheng, J., & Schloerke, B. (2024). gt: Easily Create Presentation-Ready Display Tables. R package version 0.10.1. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=gt - Enables creation of formatted, publication-ready tables - Used for displaying transition matrices with professional styling and number formatting
patchwork: Pedersen, T. L. (2024). patchwork: The Composer of Plots. R package version 1.2.1. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=patchwork - Simplifies composition of multiple ggplot2 plots - Imported for multi-plot layouts and figure combinations
webr: Andrews, B. (2024). webr: Interactive Graphics in R. R package. https://github.com/bwlewis/webr - Provides interactive visualization capabilities - Used for creating interactive pie and donut charts


Data Manipulation and Analysis
dplyr: Wickham, H., Fran√ßois, R., Henry, L., M√ºller, K., & Posit Software, PBC. (2024). dplyr: A Grammar of Data Manipulation. R package version 1.1.4. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=dplyr - Part of tidyverse ecosystem for data transformation - Used implicitly through pipes (|>) for filtering, joining, and mutating land cover data
diffeR: Pontius Jr., R. G., & Millones, M. (2011). Death to Kappa: birth of quantity disagreement and allocation disagreement for accuracy assessment. International Journal of Remote Sensing, 32(15), 4407‚Äì4429. - Specialized package for land use/cover change detection and comparison - crosstabm() function creates transition/contingency matrices from paired rasters
tidyverse: Wickham, H., Averick, M., Bryan, J., et al.¬†(2019). Welcome to the tidyverse. Journal of Open Source Software, 4(43), 1686. https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.01686 - Meta-package providing consistent data manipulation philosophy - Core dependency for all data processing workflows


Data Sources
ESA WorldCover: Zanaga, D., Van De Kerchove, R., Daems, D., De Keersmaecker, W., Brockmann, C., Kirches, G., ‚Ä¶ & Arino, O. (2021). ESA WorldCover 10 m 2020 v100. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.5571498 - 10-meter resolution global land cover dataset - Contains 11 land cover classes based on Sentinel-1 and Sentinel-2 satellite data

Semba, M. (2025). Land Cover Patterns in Mkoani District. Marine Spatial Planning Initiative, University of Dar es Salaam. Retrieved from [blog URL]

Core Project Leadership




Siajali Pamba, PhD
Role: Project Lead & Biodiversity Assessment Coordinator
Affiliation: School of Aquatic Sciences and Fisheries Technology (SOAF)
Spatial ecologist with 15+ years of experience in coastal ecosystem assessment and geospatial analysis for marine conservation planning.
Dr.¬†Pamba leads the Marine Spatial Planning Initiative as institutional lead at SOAF. She specializes in spatial pattern analysis and biodiversity assessment, developing and applying advanced geospatial methods to characterize marine ecosystem diversity and conservation priorities. Her research contributes to evidence-based marine governance in the Indian Ocean region.
